title: Are most Palestinian families originally from Palestine? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. My ancestors originate from near the Iraqi / Jordanian border. While part of my family started settling in what used to be called British Mandate Palestine, other parts of my family moved east to Baghdad. As children and young teenagers my paternal grandfather would tell me and my sister all kinds of lovely stories about his life, adventures, and businesses he used to own in Baghdad. One recurring topic was the exodus of Iraq’s Jewish communities, which he always called a great national catastrophe and personal tragedy. Iraq’s Jewish communities were one of the main import / export trading backbones and so when these communities disappeared their excellent trading connections and business relationships disappeared with them as well, as did much of the wealth they had generated and that helped sustain much of Iraqi society. This had the rather unfortunate side effect and consequence that many Arab companies, including my grandfather’s companies, slowly but surely went out of business, because they depended to a large extent on the excellent trade relationships Iraq’s Jewish communities had established and maintained for generations. My grandfather never had a bad word to say about the Jewish families with whom he did business. In fact he always told us they were the most fair, reliable, and trustworthy business people one could hope to call ones friends. To this very day my father and mother maintain that opinion and memory, because they are both old enough to remember Jordan’s iron fist occupation of the West Bank and every subsequent conflict since then. They used to tell us stories about the nationalistic lunacy that spread like wildfire throughout the West Bank and eventually resulted in the creation of the PLO, which of course wasn’t merely happy waging its ridiculous and bloody war of attrition against Israel, but also thought it wise and clever to publicly call for the overthrow of Jordan’s Hashemite Monarchy. Thanks to the excellent, fair, and honest experiences my grandfather had enjoyed with the Jewish communities in Iraq, our grandparents and parents always trusted Israeli leaders more than our own, which is why we never fled and have always remained in more or less the same part of the West Bank in which our ancestors settled. Since I and my family believe in peaceful coexistence and normalisation with liberal and pluralist Israel, we don’t see any reason why we should have to return to Jordan. However, we can understand why many Israelis think that way. Our Arab and Palestinians leaders have steadfastly refused to accept anything and everything ever offered to them that didn’t first and foremost include the eradication of all the Jews in what used to be known as British Mandate Palestine. When Anwar Sadat eventually and very bravely made peace with Israel he was assassinated by Muslim fanatics who later on went on to attack the USA in the first World Trade Center bombing of 1993. Our Palestinian leaders have never been interested in peace with Israel or the West for that matter. As already mentioned above, the PLO even thought it a good idea to try and topple and wage war against Jordan’s Hashemite Monarchy in 1970, which didn’t exactly work out too well for us either. While our Arab leaders were either fighting each other or trying to exterminate Israel, Israelis made the desert bloom, fought off countless attacks against overwhelming odds, and have made their country into the world’s most successful, liberal and pluralist high-tech startup nation. Meanwhile history has spoken and we Palestinians still keep running full speed ahead and fully armed towards the wrong side of history, which these days is nothing more than an impenetrable concrete wall / wire fence that wouldn’t need to divide anything or anybody, if it were not so necessary and successful keeping Israelis safe from our relentlessly murderous Palestinian terrorist attacks. Over the past couple of weeks Palestinian and Israeli women have marched together for peace only to be denounced by both Hamas and the BDS movement (that ironically enough always claims to be in favour of peace and against terrorism, yet clearly prefers siding with murderous Islamic terrorists instead of harmless female peace activists). It’s time for Israeli and Western liberals to realise Israeli politicians on both the right and left side of the political spectrum can continue offering peace to our Palestinian leaders as much and often as they like, safe in the knowledge our Palestinian leaders will always and forever turn down every single offer, regardless of how generous it is, unless it includes the destruction of the State of Israel and the exodus of all Jews. That said, hope dies last, as they say. For what little it’s worth, I and my wife hope for the sake of all children and grandchildren on both sides of the divide that peace is in the offing - sooner rather than later. ------ If you liked my answer or comment, please be so kind and „Upvote“ it and also consider following me. The more public support and followers I receive, the safer it is (in theory at least) for me here in the West Bank to speak my mind as freely as possible and advocate for peaceful coexistence and normalisation between our two people. Thank you most kindly, Muhammad Ibrahim Hussein & family.

First, it does not matter who local Arabs descend from. Indigenity is defined by cultural affiliation & a Time Meter. The earliest extant culture on the land is the indigenous culture. Jewish Culture is pre-invasive. In fact, when the very first Arab stepped into history IN ARABIA — in 853 BCE- Jews had a sovereign state nearly 5-centuries old. When Arabs first invaded — in 634 CE- Jews had 2,000-continuous years on the land, of which 1,100 were fully sovereign. That Jewish Culture predates Arab Culture by 2 millenia makes the issue almost comical. Arabs claim to have been present on the land when Jews invaded from the Jordanian-side of the river. They do not explain why noone in Antiquity ever mentions other groups existing upon the land after 800 BCE. The Phillistines were extinct by then as were the various Canaanite Tribes. As for the Phillistines, the group that Palestinians & some of their supporters focus upon, as "Palestinian" Is after all the Greek bastardisation of the label "Phillistine" — they were Proto Greek invaders from the Aegaean isles off of Greece. Their culture was Mycanaean and centered upon the island of Crete. Local Arabs claim to be European invaders while simultaneoudly pointing their finger at Israelis, whom they usually insist are..."European invaders." Kafkaesque does not begin to describe it. Need to add, other answers neglected a couple of points. The first is that the only details we have of the three Jewish Roman Wars come to us from Roman propagandists. Even Josephus, the Jewish traitor who defected to Rome was a highly biased propagandist. D-o Cassius? Tacitus? They all primarily relied upon word of mouth gossip to come up with their figures. In the 7th Century CE the last pre modern Jewish State — the Sassanian Jewish Commonwealth — fell just 20-months before the Arabs invaded. In order to re-establish Jewish sovereignity over all of the land there had to be a sizable & stable number of Jews living upon the land. Galilee, Golan & much of Judaea still had a population that was mostly Jewish, Even after the Arab invasion Jews remained the majority in Galilee until the late-18th Century. Likewise in Golan until the 1830s. Unfortunately, they did not remain so in Judaea after the Second Crusade. Still, in Jerusalem they have always held a solid majority except during periodic bans on Jewish residency. Palestinians are of course Arabs. Every Palestinian Tribe & clan are part of the Qais- Yamani Confederacies. They speak Arabic as a first language and would never dare to claim that they do not practice Arab Culture. Since Arabs first arrived on the land as invaders, Palestinians practice an invasive culture. Even If they could somehow sell the fantasy that they are the descendents of Phillistines & Cana'anites, their invasive culture abrogates any indigenous status. Lastly, depending upon the study you choose, 6 to 8% of Palestinians are in fact the direct descendents of Jews & the closely-related Samaritans. Those directly descended from Jews cluster in Hebron District in Judaea. Those descending from Samaritans cluster in Nablus District in Samaria. As noted, that still doesn't make them indigenous, but invaders.

I sincerely doubt it, based on their family names. Despite the ‘tongue in cheek’ title, the link provides a list of common Palestinian family names and their ethnic origins. I regard ‘Palestinian’ as a political, rather than ethnic identifier. Pretending to be Canaanites or Philistines only undermines their credibility. Lots of countries are populated by people of assorted ethnic backgrounds. It shouldn’t be an issue. "Zionists trying to hide Canaanite-Palestinian civilization" I think the issue is only relevant if you are trying to give the impression that you have more rights to a place than the other guy. In this case, the other guy is Israel, and by the standard the Palestinians are trying to use (history vs mythology) the Israelis win. Archeology and history prove it. Additionally, genetic studies place the origins of Palestinians outside the Levant. Genome-Wide Diversity in the Levant Reveals Recent Structuring by Culture Again, while it’s interesting and debunks their ethnic origin claim, it’s still largely irrelevant to creating a viable Palestinian state. Negotiate borders, make a state, and get on with it. Unless the real motive of the Palestinians isn’t a 2-State solution at all.

Anonymous brings the data of population growth in what used to be the province of Palestine and claims that there is no foundation to the thesis that there was any form of massive Arab migration before the establishment of Israel.I disagree on four counts:1. There is no explanation for the sudden doubling and then quadrupling of the Arab population between 1923 and 1947. It couldn’t be natural because the main driver for decreasing infant mortality and increased life expectancy has always been medical treatment and in particular the advent of antibiotics which were only introduced to the first world countries in 1939. 2. Historically the area has always been one of migrations. During the Ottoman rule and even more so under the British mandate, especially in the turbulent post WW II world.3. Much as Muhammad Ibrahim Hussein describes, most of today’s Israeli Arabs and Palestinians in the Occupied territories have family connections throughout the Middle East. Jordan, Iraq, Syria and Lebanon mostly. I’m not referring to the refugee camps but to well established families thriving throughout the Arab middle east.4. The first buds of the Palestinian National Movement around the early 1920’s identified with the pan-Arab notion of a greater Syria and not with a distinct Palestinian nation-state. That came much later and to a great extent as a reaction to Zionism. This of course has nothing to do with the fact that Palestinians today identify themselves as a national identity. I don’t argue with self determination. I do argue with the reinvention of historical facts.

There is a problem with the definition used to define a Palestinian refugee. The definition the UN set up when they established the UNRWA was any person who lived in the British Mandate of Palestine a minimum of 3 years prior to the establishment of the State of Israel. So someone could have moved to the British Mandate in 1945 from Egypt, Jordan, Iran, wherever, and then claimed refugee status in 1949. Furthermore, Palestinian refugees are the only refugee group where the status passes on in each generation. So even children of Palestinian refugees born outside the country inherit their parent's status. And there is no limit to how many generations it can be passed down. So the numbers grow at the rate of population growth. When you combine that with how Jordan, Egypt and Syria have established that the Palestinians who have been living in their refugee camps have restricted travel, an incredibly hard time to actually become citizens in that country and cannot own property in certain areas, the problem perpetuates itself.

Yes, although you’ll get a lot of convoluted answers talking about non-existent mass migrations that aren’t born out by census data, or comments about names that supposedly “reveal country of origin.” Doing genealogy on my own English family, everyone was convinced that our name Wellman meant our ancestor was from Wales. Turns out he was the Well man, who kept the wells clean, in Somerset England. Another ancestor, I was told, was a Native American. She was always called ‘the Indian.” Turns out, she was from Indiana, and not an Indian. The same can be true of some Palestinian names, whom Israelis chose to interpret as indicating they are from other countries and not Palestinian. Its possible that a thousand years ago, some one did come from Egypt into Palestine. Abraham was a Chaldean from Ur and not an Israeli.

Sadly the other two answers here seem to be politicized, as so many topics that even remotely touch Israel are on this site.  I don't know of any person that identifies as a Palestinian who's family is not originally from the region that is now Israel,  the West Bank, and Gaza. Many Palestinian families have not lived there for a generation or more, having been part of the 750,000 Palestinians expelled in 1948, or the second wave in 1967. But they trace their families to the region, often grandparents or parents, and in my experience most can tell you the name of the town or village their family was from.  There is no evidence that most Palestinians are not from the region, though there have been claims made by some political partisans, most notably the discredited book "From Time Immemorial" which claimed most Palestinians were recent immigrants to the Mandate of Palestine. That claim has been credibly debunked by numerous historians and demographers, including Israeli ones.

Are most Palestinian families originally from Palestine? Some family names (Nisbah) of Arabs living in Palestine more than 1000 years ago , reveal their country of origin: Note : al Falastini means (The Palestinian / of Palestine) 1-Abu Umran al Falastini 2-Abu al Zubayr al Falastini 3-Abu al Husain al Falastini 4-Yahiya Ibn Hasaan al Falastini 5-Domra Ibn ar rabi’aa al Falastini 6-Hajar Ibn al harith al Ghassani ( he lived in Palestine however his surname was al Ghassani which indicates that he is a descendant of the Arab Ghassanids who migrated from Yemen to the Levant some 1800 years ago) 7-Na’im Ibn Salama al Saba’i ( Ghassanid Arab , lived in Palestine and Damascus , his surname indicates that his origin from Saba , Yemen like the rest of the Ghassanids ) 8-Jabla Ibn Attia al Falastini 9-Salama “ Abu Na’im “ ( Na’ims father (no 7) , lived in Palestine , his origin : Ghassanid Arab ) 10-Hanei Ibn Abi Abla al Falastini 11-Galip Ibn Vezir al Falastini 12-Abdullah Ibn Ziyad al Falastini 13-Abdullah Ibn Maaj al Falastini 14- AbdulJalil al Falastini 15-Abu Suleyman al Falastini 16-Abu Razin al Falastini 17-Hanei Ibn Abdurahman Ibn Abi Abla al Falastini All such names of Hadith narrators were mentioned during the Middle ages by Arab scholars , on the other hand let us investigate the (Nisbah) of Jewish Rabbis : 1- Nachman of Horodenka = From Horodenka Ukraine 2 Aaron of Pinsk = From Pinsk Belarus 3- Chaim Yosef Gottlieb of Stropkov = From Stropkov Slovakia 4-Yaakov Moshe Lorberbaum of Lissa = Leszno/Lissa Poland 5-Shneur Zalman of Liadi = Liadi/Lyady Vitbesk Belarus 6- Eleazar of Worms = Worms Germany 7- Aharon of Karlin = Karlin Pinsk Belarus ( an entire Hasidic dynasty is based in Karlin) 8- Dov Ber of Mezeritch = From Velyki Mezhyrichi Ukraine 9- Elimelech of Lizhensk = From Leżajsk Poland 10 -Levi Yitzchok of Berditchev = From Berdychiv Ukraine In his 2019 book “ The Palestinian Delusion “ Robert B Spencer M.A has claimed that , Palestinians are invented people , he writes : the term Palestinians and “ Palestinian people “ were invented during the 60’s by the KGB and it’s Arab allies ! the same claims were repeated by Prof Daniel Pipes , Caroline Glick , Mark Humphrys among others The Palestinian Delusion: The Catastrophic History of the Middle East Peace Process Actually , not only our Ottoman documents used terms like Palestine and Palestinians , but even Medieval Arab sources used both terms , many Hadith narrators appeared in many books with “ al falastini / The Palestinian “ as a surname , Nisbah . Al Baladhuri (died 892 AD ) in his book Futuh Al Buldan ( Translated by Philip K Hitti 1916 Columbia University ) has stated the following in p298:  So the term “Palestinian” and Plestinian people wasn’t invented by the KGB and it’s Arab allies during the 60’s as Zionist professors and academics are falsely promoting .

No. A case in point was pointed out yesterday by MK Dr. Anat Berko: A few years ago Saeb Erakat, a professional Palestinian negotiator, decided he was a Canaanite, descendant of a tribe that was here before 1200 BC (Joshua's conquest), in order to try and out-native the Jews. As soon as rumors started ensuing in the PA that some Jewish blood was mixed in this lineage over the generations, he was very quick to recant and confess that he is, in fact, a Jordanian Bedouin.

Many Palestinian families and most Israeli families aren’t from Palestine. By saying originally from, we are implying natives of the land. Many Palestinians came from the Levantine and North African regions, and most Israelis today are of European descent. Most Palestinians you see today have been there for hundreds and thousands of years though, many of whom converted from Judaism to Christianity and Islam. The large Jewish population, that makes up most of Israel’s population, come from Europe as there was a mass migration of Jews after WWII. There had also been migration of Jews from countries such as Yemen, Algeria, and Iraq. You can usually tell if someone is a native by them having a mix of Middle Eastern DNA and possibly slight “Jewish” DNA. Palestine has been invaded time and time again throughout history so it’s sort of a mixing bowl of people from different places. For example, you had the Romans, the Ottomans, etc… the only way to really tell if someone is an actual native is through their DNA and family history.

Simple data taken from any reliable source pre 1900 proves very few are. Additionally, most family names are not Ottoman. But mostly this misses the point — all so called Palestinians in both Judea/Sameria and Gaza belong to tribes and those tribes are affiliated with larger clans, most of which are located in other countries.

That's a great question. The truth is hard data is unavailable, so the best we have to go on is guesswork.  The Ottomans were not very diligent about taking census data, and when they did, people had an incentive to fudge the numbers to avoid taxes.  While it's known there was significant Arab immigration during the time of British rule, the brits didn't keep track of it so it's unknown how extensive it was.  It is known that prior to the 20th century the region was described as desolate and sparsely populated.   It is also known that of the Arabic refugees from the Israeli war of independence, called the "Nakba" by some, those that tried to return to homes in places such as Egypt, Iraq, Syria or Lebanon were turned away and not allowed to return and had Palestinian identity forced upon them.

That depends on what you mean with “originally”. Originally humans developed in East Africa. Palestinians arrived in Palestine at various times through the millennia and are a mix of people with various origin (just like the rest of us). This answer to another question might be relevant: Someone anonymous's answer to Who were the ancestors of most of the Palestinians currently living in Gaza and West Bank? Were they Jewish? If not, who were they?

No people continue to live in the same place that their ancestors originally came from. Palestinians claim to be Arabs which means they come from Arabia. DNA studies do however show that they share some ancestry with Jews and Lebanese. This likely means that some Palestinians have ancestry that is common to other people who trace their ancestry to the same region.

Land only belongs to those with the strength—militarily, economically, politically, and willpower—to hold on to it. So, the history of Jews and Arabs is fascinating, but ultimately, it’s irrelevant. Israel and its Jewish majority own and govern the land on which the nation sits, and until somebody stronger comes along to invade and seize it to create their own nation, Israel will stay where it is. Jews took back their historic homeland in geographic Palestine, named it the State of Israel, built a vast culture and infrastructure, and has the means and willpower to defend it from invaders. Arabs had the right to take (roughly) half of Palestine for a nation of their own when the Mandate ended, but chose war instead—unwisely, to utter dismay. As has happened on every patch of land on Earth at any given time in history.

Are most American families originally from America? Are most Canadian families originally from Canada? Are most British families originally from Britain? Its upto the Palestinians to determine who is a Palestinian. They haven't outsourced that right to anyone else.

Can I ask a question , then you can find the answer , all answers here are politicals … Are most Syrians originally from Syria ? No Are most Jordanians originally from Jordan ? No Are most Turks from originally turkey ? No Are most Lebanese from originally Lebanon ! No Are most isrealis originally from Israel ? No so don’t tell me about Palestine .. we all immigrants.,

Some Palestinian family names reveal the original family origin. Mograbi indicates that the family migrated from the Morocco area (Maghrib in Arabic). The name Masarwi comes from Misr, which is Egypt in Arabic. I once read a number of other examples, but those are the two I remember.

If you go far enough back, everyone’s originally from Africa. More usefully, in 1800,most ancestors of modern Palestinians did not live in what is now Israel and Palestine. Most ancestry of the current Arab population of the region came in several waves of immigration that started in the early-to-mid 1800s and lasted for several decades.

First there is no country named Palestine, it is an area that the British called Palestine following the World War 1 settlement and the people there did not call themselves Palestinians until after 1948 when Israel was made a state. The Arabs were offered the same as Israel back then BUT they decided it was theirs and no Israel it was all or nothing. Jordan was also created and the surrounding Arab countries refused to accept any of the Arabs so War broke out between Israel and the Arabs and Israel was established. The Arabs continually start wars trying to wipe out Israel but lose every time. The 1967 Six Day War was started by Israel only because the Arab Nations were arming themselves and getting ready for an all out attack on Israel so Israel attacked first and won. This was when Israel took East Jerusalem and and claimed the whole city as Israel. The PLO was a political party of the Arabs.
My family is originally from Palestine (Nablus). It was proven from family DNA testing that my family was traced back to the Tribe of Levi.
What happened to our friend Muhammad? I've stunned to see that his account was banned. What can we all do to support him???
If their family name is Al Masri, they originate from Egypt.
No
